//Simran Jeet Singh Strings
Simran Jeet Singh An activist who advocates for religious equality in America Gender: Male Pronouns: He/Him Age: 36 Race: American Simran Jeet Singh was born on July 25, 1984, in San Antonio, Texas. Growing up, there were not a lot of Sikh families where he lived and his parents felt it was important to stay connected to their culture. Singh started learning Punjabi from a young age and also consistently did kirtan and ardas (religious practices) , as there were no Gurdwaras (Sikh places of worship) where he lived. His community was small and they met on Friday nights but Singh also had friends who weren’t Sikh. He felt like he was living in two different worlds.
Singh went to camps around America during the years that were connected with Sikhi but he didn’t feel truly (tied) until he started learning about the recent history of his people. He learned he was named by his parents after a famous political activist at the time. From these places came his inspiration to help his community. From his emotional connections came his spiritual connections to the world.
After 9/11, Singh realized that identity includes how other people view you as well as how you view yourself. He saw himself being grouped into places while his community was turning invisible, trying to explain their story. 9/11 showed him the pain and ignorance people show towards certain religions and faiths. He felt he had the responsibility and privilege, that others didn’t have, to change that.
Today, Simran Jeet Singh is a writer, a professor at Columbia University, and a Senior Religion Fellow for the Sikh Coalition, and a Truman National Security Fellow for the Truman National Security Project. He has multiple degrees from Harvard and Columbia University and has a podcast called Spirited where he talks about leaders and activists. He has also written a book called Fauja Singh Keeps Going about the oldest person who was believed to run a marathon. He lives with his two children and his wife.
http://www.wearesikhs.org/simran_jeet_singh https://theconversation.com/profiles/simran-jeet-singh-486698#:~:text=Born%20and%20raised%20in%20San,at%20Weill%20Cornell%20Medical%20College.
//Simran Jeet Singh Quiz
1. Where was Singh born where there were not many Sikh families at the time? Antipolo, Philippines Sacramento, California Mingora, Swat valley, Pakistan San Antonio, Texas
2. When did Simran Jeet Singh begin feeling truly tied to the culture of his people? When he started going to Gurdwaras at a young age When he began learning about the recent history of his people When 9/11 occurred When he performed religious practices with his family
3. Who was Simran Jeet Singh named after? A famous singer at the time A famous drum player at the time A famous political activist at the time A famous painter at the time
4. What did Singh see after 9/11? He saw himself being grouped into places while his community was turning invisible He saw himself being more ignorant towards people of other races He saw large amounts of others grouping themselves into certain religious categories He saw that all races and religions were treated equally
5. What is Simran Jeet Singh’s podcast “Spirited” about? His favorite books about painting Leaders and activists Political parties in America His favorite foods
//Alice Wong Strings
Alice Wong Pronouns: She/Her Gender: Female Age: 46 Activist for the rights of disabled people Alice Wong was born in Indianapolis, Indiana on March 24, 1974, with Spinal Muscular Atrophy (SMA). As a young girl, she always felt lonely being a wheel-chair user. It was a three-hour drive from her home to buy lunch and groceries as Chinese-Americans living in Indiana. She found the distance made her appreciate the food more. She also experienced bullying at schools. Her classmates would push her and hit her because she was weak and her teachers did not make enough accommodations for people with disabilities. Wong became a sociologist and learned about different groups and what they meant. From there, she started thinking about disabilities as less of just a biological difference but also how it affected people mentally. She found she had a lot of anger due to her disability which she started channeling into writing and research. She experienced microaggressions from others towards people with disabilities such as when she was denied a drama course because she would not be able to be “physical enough”.
In early 2014, she started developing the Disability Visibility Project after she attended a StoryCorps event in San Francisco for animated portions on NPR’s Morning Edition. She found it left a lasting impression on her and reached out to someone to ask if they were interested in creating a project with a disability community-specific partnership. The project was launched in July 2014 to help document the experiences of people with disabilities. Wong has also written an essay published in Amerasia Journal, “Musings from an Angry Asian American Disabled Girl”, where she wrote about her experiences growing up. She strives to connect young women and girls with disabilities to empower them.
https://letterstothrive.tumblr.com/post/55608302401/hey-angry-girl https://www.easterseals.com/thrive/who-we-are/alice-wong.html https://disabilityvisibilityproject.com/2015/12/12/dvp-interview-alice-wong-and-ellen-wu/
//Alice Wong Quiz
1. What condition was Alice Wong born with? Autism Spectrum Disorder Spinal Muscular Atrophy Kernicterus Myotonic dystrophy
2. How did becoming a sociologist influence Wong\’s thinking? She started thinking about disabilities as not only a biological difference but also how they affected people mentally She started thinking about how race influenced the way people thought of disabilities She started thinking about the way that the food people ate influenced their disabilities She started thinking about disabilities as not only a biological difference but also thinking about how they affected people politically
3. In which experience did Wong feel a micro-aggression towards people with disabilities? When her teacher told her she could not play in the soccer game because she was not strong enough When her best friend told her they couldn\’t be friends because she wasn\’t smart enough When her sister told her that she could not go shopping with her because she wasn\’t pretty enough When she was denied a drama course because they said she would not be able to be physical enough
4. What is the Disability Visibility Project? A project Alice Wong developed to help people see again A project Wong\’s sister developed to connect people with disabilities to connect them to people in senior centers A project Alice Wong developed to allow people to learn about the stories of people with disabilities A project Alice Wong developed for student’s to raise awareness about climate change
5. What is Alice Wong\’s essay in Amerasia Journal, “Musings from an Angry Asian American Disabled Girl” about? Her experiences as a disabled Asian American growing up Her story about someone knocking over her basket in a grocery store Her story about creating her own school Her experiences growing up in a busy city
//Thandiwe Abdullah Strings
Thandiwe Abdullah Pronouns: She/Her Gender: Female Age: 17 Activist for anti-racism and equality movements Thandiwe Abdullah was born in the Crenshaw District Los Angeles California in 2003. She was born to an activist family and started attending Black Lives Matter meetings at the young age of 10. Along with this, she was raised by many strong African American women in her community. Her mom was a professor of Pan African Studies at CSULA and she later (became) a co-founder of the LA chapter of Black Lives Matter. The founders of the Black Lives Matter Movement, Patrisse Kahn Cullors, Opal Tometti, and Alicia Garza, taught her to expand her thinking. She learned about pronouns, gender fluidity, and more about African American culture. However, Abdullah realized that she and her siblings were the only children being raised by the movement despite its goal to encourage a family community. She felt the effects of colorism, being called prettier because she was “lighter-skinned” and realized that lighter skin girls were more heard. In school, she felt as if she was fitting into the “angry Black girl mold” that society perpetuated. People around her wanted her to stop but she would not stop her activism and calling people out on their racism.
She felt she did not fit into the women’s rights movement, that it was just white women who talked about microaggressions and the wage gap. However, she noticed that African American women get paid 21% less than an average white woman. She wanted to bring to light the privilege that some people have that others do not and to make sure movements reflect all people they stand for. Today, Abdullah says she works for all her sisters and people of color. She is an activist in the Black Lives Matter movement and a co-founder of Black Lives Matter Youth Vanguard which is a program to help Black youth, specifically in the LA area. She is greatly dedicated to her activism and changing the world to make sure no one has to worry about affording basic human needs.
https://www.seventeen.com/life/a34717855/thandiwe-abdullah-black-lives-matter-voices-of-the-year-2020/
//Thandiwe Abdullah Quiz Strings
1. At what age did Abdullah begin attending Black Lives Matter meetings? 20 17 6 10
2. What did she learn from the founders of the Black Lives Matter Movement (Patrisse Kahn Cullors, Opal Tometti, and Alicia Garza)? Pronouns, gender fluidity, and African American culture How to read and speak English How to recognize when someone has a disability Asian American culture and the differences in languages around the globe
3. Which mold did Abdullah say she felt like she was being put into at school? “angry Black girl” “smart Asian boy” “unintelligent Black girl” “cheerful American boy”
4. What did Abdullah want to bring to light after learning about after learning that an African American woman gets paid 21% less than an average white woman despite feeling like the majority of the women\'s rights movement? The money that others have that they can give to immigrants The privilege that others have that they should not use because it is not fair to others The education that some people have that others do not that they should use to teach seniors. The privilege that some people have that others do not and to make sure movements reflect all people they stand for
5. What is the Black Lives Matter Youth Vanguard? A program to help Asian A program to help Black youth A program to help disabled youth A program to help immigrants
//Beverly Palesa Ditsie Strings
Beverly Palesa Ditsie Pronouns: She/Her Gender: Female Age: 50 Activist for LGBTQ+ rights Beverly Palesa Ditsie was born in 1970 in Soweto, South Africa. From the age of 10, she acted in movies as an actress and voice actor. She grew up in her grandmother’s home and always felt like she was surrounded by love there. Her grandmother was a rock to her, a pillar of the community as she watched her struggle but pursue. She also valued her grandmother’s husband and her mother a lot. Ditsie’s call to activism was when she became a student council representative in her high school. She always thought that there was an “overpowering” masculinity that surrounded the system. She was frustrated and spent a lot of time with queer boys, starting with them their first meeting of Glow [the Gay and Lesbian Organisation of the Witwatersrand]. There she met Simon Nkoli who she later directed the movie Simon and I about. He was an older brother figure to her who helped raise voices for the LQBTQA+ community. Glow was deeply rooted in intersectionality. In NGO spaces, Ditsie began to make sure all voices were included and pointed out deep exclusion in communities.
Glow helped wth the formation of the National Coalition for Gay and Lesbian Equality (NCGLE) which ensured that rights based on gender and sexuality were included in South Africa’s new constitution at the time. Ditsie spoke at the 1995 United Nations Conference on Women in Bejing, being the first person, an African lesbian woman to talk, about LGBTQA+ rights at a UN Convention. She spoke about how discrimination based on sexual orientation was a violation of basic human rights and it was neccessary to address that before talking about any other concerns of women. Ditsie struggled with her mental health through her activism, living through apartheid, and the imposter syndrome she experienced because of her gender. Ditsie continued making films to bring attention to people in the LGBTQA+ community and people with HIV/AIDs. Her film Simon and I became very popular and displayed a clear message about what she fought for, freedom. Today she continues her activism to inspire and help others. In 2019, she was a recipient of an honorary degree from Claremont Graduate University in California, United States for her activism and fight to bring justice to people in society.
https://sandtonchronicle.co.za/lnn/299767/celebrating-bev-ditsie-for-her-role-in-making-lgbti-rights-a-reality https://lovemattersafrica.com/sexual-diversity/beverly-palesa-ditsie-a-pioneer-for-african-intersectionality https://www.wmm.com/filmmaker/Beverley+Palesa+Ditsie/ https://www.sahistory.org.za/dated-event/beverly-palesa-ditsie-first-out-lesbian-woman-address-united-nations-about-lgbt-rights https://www.theguardian.com/society/2020/aug/20/beverley-ditsie-the-south-african-woman-who-helped-liberate-lesbians-everywhere https://www.newframe.com/beverley-ditsie-comes-full-circle/
1. What was Ditsie\’s call to activism? When her best friend became an activist for Disability rights When she attended one of her school’s GLOW club meetings and felt she had a responsibility to start her own club When she became a student council representative in her high school because she thought that there was “overpowering” masculinity that surrounded the system When her grandmother died and she felt she could never be like her
2. Who was a mentor to Ditsie that guided her in her fight for LGBTQ+ rights? Laverne Cox Simon Nkoli Bruce Wayne Anne Hathaway
3. What is the National Coalition for Gay and Lesbian Equality (NCGLE)? An organization that brought light to LGBTQ+ issues in senior centers An organization that ensured that rights based on gender and sexuality were included in South Africa’s new constitution at the time An organization that ensured rights based on disabilities were included in South Africa’s new constitution at the time An organization that brought light to issues based on the lack of education about diversity in South Africa\’s schools
4. Ditsie was the first person, an African lesbian woman to talk, about LGBTQA+ rights at a UN Convention. What specifically did she speak about? She spoke about how discrimination based on sexual orientation was a violation of basic human rights and it was necessary to address that before talking about any other concerns of women She spoke about the lack of female artists in the music industry She spoke about how discrimination based on the ability level was a violation of human rights She spoke about how her friends who immigrated to Africa and felt alone
5. What was Ditsie\’s Film “Simon and I” about? Ditsie\’s father Simon, an education activist who passed away due to old age Ditsie\’s friend Simon, a disability rights activist who passed away due to their condition Ditsie\’s brother Simon, a religious equality activist who passed away due to AIDS Ditsie\’s mentor Simon, a gay right’s activist who passed away due to AIDS
//Malala Yousafzai Strings
Malala Yousafzai Pronouns: She/Her Gender: Female Age: 23 Activist for Education Malala Yousafzai was born July 12, 1997 in Mingora, Swat valley, Pakistan. She was the daughter of a social activist and an educator. Her father settled and took care of the school she went to, Khushal Girls High School and College. Her father always encouraged her to become educated and follow his path. However, the Swat Valley was invaded in 2007 by the TTP, e Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan, who wanted to get rid of any chances for women to play an active role in society and become educated. Yousafzai and her family were forced to flee. When she was 11 years old, Yousafzai’s father took her to a press club in Peshawar where she gave her first speech named, “How Dare the Taliban Take Away My Basic Right to Education?”. It became popular all throughout Pakistan and The British Broadcasting Corporation (BBC) approached Yousafzai’s father for someone to write blog posts for them about their experience living under TTP rule. Yousafzai started writing in Urdu, later translated to English, under the name of Gul Makai. She wrote 35 entires.
In 2009, Yousafzai was interviewed for Capital Talk, a Pakistani talk show. Although the TPP was started allowing girls to attend school again, on the condition they wear burkas, violence started again. The New York Times reporter Adam Ellick made a short film with Malala about her school shutting down. Malala became more famous and received Pakistan’s first National Youth Peace Prize. In late 2012, Malala was shot coming home from school by a gunman of the TTP. She survived and her story led to the UN special envoy for global education, Gordon Brown, making a petition to put all children back in school by 2015. This led to the legalization of Pakistan\'s first Right to Education bill. Malala later co-authored the book I Am Malala: The Girl Who Stood Up for Education and Was Shot by the Taliban (2013) with Christina Lamb and became the youngest person to win the Nobel Peace Prize. Malala maintained attending school in England and started her own girls school in Lebanon for refugees from the Syrian War using funding from the Malala Fund. In 2020, she finished her Philosophy, Politics and Economics degrees at Oxford. She still continues on her fight for equality and education for everyone today.
https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/malala-yousafzai-graduates-college-8-years-after-taliban-gunned-her-n1231525 https://www.britannica.com/biography/Malala-Yousafzai
1. What did Yousafzai’s father always encourage her to do? Follow in his footsteps to become educated and teach Follow in his footstep to become an artist and spread messages through music Follow in her friend\’s footsteps to become a doctor Follow in her uncle\’s footsteps to become an archeologist
2. When she was 11 years old, Yousafzai’s father took her to a press club in Peshawar. She gave a speech that reached the BBC and became very popular throughout the world. What was the name of the speech? “How Dare the Taliban Take Away My Family?” “Who am I and why do I do what I do?” “Who are the Taliban and Why Are They Here?” “How Dare the Taliban Take Away My Basic Right to Education?”
3. The New York Times reporter Adam Ellick made a short film with Malala about what? Her family being taken away by the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan Her public library being shut down by the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan Her school being shut down by the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan Her best friends moving to another country
4. What happened in late 2012 when Malala was coming home from school? She was shot by a gunman from the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan She befriended a gunman from the Tehrik-e-Taliban Pakistan She found a dog in the wild to take home She found money to create her own movie
5. For which of these did Malala use money from the Malala Fund to support? Her own senior center in New York from veterans from WII Her own library in Texas for everyone to use Her own girl\’s school in Lebanon for refugees from the Syrian War Her own girl\’s school in Pakistan for those who have schools shut down by the Taliban
//Melanie Campbell Strings
Melanie Campbell Pronouns: She/Her Gender: Female Anti-Racism and Equal Rights Activist
Melanie Campbell was born in Mims, Fla. on the Allantic coast as the youngest of six children. Her parents led the local chapter of the NAACP (National Association for the Advancement of Colored People) organization. They were active in their role and Melanie remembers one night, where was sleeping on the floor, close to her mother and siblings, while her father and a few other men were outside getting ready to defend the town from an attack by the Klu Klux Klan that still existed in the 1950s in Florida. Melanie enrolled and graduated from Clark Atlanta University, after she had followed her brothers and sisters, and after graduation she got a job in the corporate world. Despite this, Campbell began missing the activism and the movement and started working for Maynard Jackson, Atlanta’s mayor at the time and a high-profile Black political leader. She ran the mayor\'s office for youth services and hired Stacey Abrams, a student from Spelman College, who asked Jackson about if he really understood the feelings of younger people. Campbell began working hard towards the rise of youth voices.
Campbell moved to Washington by 1995 and started working at the National Coalition on Black Civic Participation and in 2000 became the executive director and in 2011 the president and CEO. She spoke about how her life mission was to make sure Black women were not invisible. She was recognized as one of Washington D.C.\'s Top Forty Under Forty Emerging Leaders in 2000. She also convened Black Women’s Roundtable which is a non-partisan organization that is, according to Washington Post, “one of the largest networks of women focused on using civic engagement to improve the lives of Black women, their families and their communities — improving access to health care, ending systemic racism, reforming the criminal justice system, lifting people out of poverty.” Campbell’s other accomplishments include convening the Voices of the Electorate National Election Reform Task Force and being a main trainer in 1996 for the West African Women\'s Colloquium in Ghana, West Africa. Currently, she advocates for bringing leadership opportunities for the next generation and bringing equality and fairness, especially for Black girls and women. She has been a features writer at the National Urban League’s State of Black America and has received the “Sustainer of the Flame Freedom Flame Award” by The Bridge Crossing Jubilee.
https://www.washingtonpost.com/politics/this-is-how-democracy-crumbles-melanie-campbell-on-the-fight-to-defend-black-votes/2020/11/02/6d2a4884-1d0a-11eb-b532-05c751cd5dc2_story.html https://www.ncbcp.org/who/bios/mcampbell/ https://iop.harvard.edu/fellows/melanie-campbell
1. When Campbell was growing up in Mims, Florida, her parents led the local chapter of what organization? To make sure everyone was well educated about climate change To ensure that all people could talk about their favorite subjects in school To make sure Black women were not invisible To abolish the health care system
2. What event did Campbell say she remembered where she was sleeping on the floor, close to her brother, sister, and mother while something else was happening? Her grandfather going to the grocery store alone because everyone was too tired Her father and others ready to defend the town from an attack by the Klu Klux Klan Her grandmother was in the hospital after a heart attack Her best friend was moving away to another country
3. Who did Campbell hire after starting to work for Atlanta\’s Mayor, Maynard Jackson, at the time? Joe Jackson because he was a mentor to Campbell and taught her much about politics Alexandra Jackson because she was Maynard Jackson\’s daughter Michael Jackson because he was famous and well known at the time Stacey Abrams because she questioned if Jackson really understood and acknowledged the feelings of younger people
4. What did Campbell say one of her main life goals was when she became the president and CEO of the National Coalition on Black Civic Participation? To make sure everyone was well educated about climate change To ensure that all people could talk about their favorite subjects in school To make sure Black women were not invisible To abolish the health care system
5. Campbell convened the Black Women’s Roundtable which is a non-partisan organization which is which of the following? A network of women to improve the lives of Black women, their families, and communities A network of women to spread their favorite books and speak about them A weekly meeting in which women discuss career paths and education for seniors A weekly meeting in which young Black girls discuss their experiences in life
//Chad Griffin Strings
Chad Griffin Pronouns: He/Him Gender: Male LGTBQ+ Rights Activist
Chad Griffin was born on July 16, 1973 in Arkansas. He went to school in Southern Baptist Church and was often bullied and teased for being gay. He was confused about his sexuality by this, admitting to Washington post he did not know he was gay. Growing up, he had a deep passion for international affairs and politics and had one job as a page at the state Capitol. He attended Ouachita Baptist University and volunteered for the 1992 presidential campaign of Bill Clinton, dropping out at 19 to become the youngest member of presidential staff. He was at the White House for two years before he started attending Georgetown University\'s School of Foreign Service. Just before he graduated in 1997 he received an offer for a State Department job which he declined when he got an offer from Rob Reiner who was an actor, director, and political activist who he had met in the White House a few years before. He and Reiner established the I Am Your Child Foundation, a charitable foundation which helped parents and caregivers understand child development better.
Griffin started his own consulting firm in 1998 and was hired by Reiner to pass Proposition 10 which would put a tax on tobacco products and give the profits to the effects it left on children. He worked on a number of other propositions such as Proposition 71 in 2004 and Proposition 8 in 2008. He was a strong opponent of Propostion 8, which held that only marriage between man and a woman were valid in California, and as an open homosexual, he was deeply upset by the loss. He and Reiner took a different approach the the situation, going to the US Supereme Court and arguing that that marriage is a fundamental right and if same-sex couples were denied it, it would violate the U.S. Constitution\'s guarantee of equal protection. On February 7, 2012, Proposition 8 was ruled unconstitutional. Griffin, in 2013, was 16th on Out magazine\'s "Power 50" list of the 50-most powerful LGBT individuals in the United States. Today, Griffin is still a strong activist for LGBTQ+ rights. In 2018, he stepped down as the president of the Human Rights Campaign which he has directed for the past years. He also founded the American Foundation for Equal Rights. Griffin was also a producer for the documentary Outrage which highlighted political figures who had worked against LGBT rights and their allegations and claims against homosexuality.
https://peoplepill.com/people/chad-griffin/ https://apnews.com/article/b872e8f19255470fbb504ef1040df2bf https://civilrights.org/2019/04/29/hrcs-chad-griffin-to-receive-chairpersons-award-at-civil-rights-dinner/ http://www.glbtqarchive.com/ssh/griffin_chad_S.pdf
1. Growing up, Griffin had a deep passion for which subjects? Math and Science International affairs and politics International business and finance Computer Science and Data Analysis
How many years did Griffin serve in the White House after volunteering in a political campaign at age 19 and under which president? 3 years; Hillary Clinton 2 years; Bill Clinton 5 years; Barack Obama 1 year; Donald Trump
Griffin was a strong opponent of Proposition 8 in 2008 because of his own identity as a gay man. What did Proposition 8 state? “Eliminates Right of Same-Sex Couples to Marry” “Eliminates Right of Same-Sex Couples to Appear in Public” “Right of Same-Sex Couples to Marry” “Right of Same-Sex Couples to Get Married in a Different Country”
Which campaign did Griffin step down that he had been leading over the past few years? The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People Human Rights Campaign United Nations Free and Equal Green America
What is the documentary “Outrage”, which Griffin was one of the producers of, about? Popular authors who wrote about LQBTQ+ during their time Popular singers who were also part of the LGBTQ+ community and spoke up for their rights Political figures who had worked against LGBTQ+ rights and their allegations and claims against homosexuality Political figures who worked for LGBTQ+ rights
//Jose Antonio Vargas Strings
Jose Antonio Vargas Pronouns: He/Him Gender: Male Advocating for immigrants and the Latinx community
Jose Antonio Vargas was born on February 3, 1981 in Antipolo in the Philippines. He was smuggled into the United States at a young age. At the age of 16 when Vargas was going to the DMV to get his license, the clerk informed him it was fake. Vargas went back home and questioned his grandparents who were naturalized American citizens. His grandfather admitted to him that his documents were purchased and fake. From then, Vargas felt like he had to prove his American identity. Vargas began watching movies to learn about the culture and aspects of life in America. Hec graduated from Mountain View High School in 2000 and graduated from San Francisco State University in 2004. He was later named Alumnus of the year in 2012. He created multiple works that entail the journey of his life; a New York Times Magazine essay, “My Life as an Undocumented Immigrant”, a Time cover story in 2012, “Not Legal Not Leaving”, and a 2013 film, Documented. Following these works, Vargas wrote a memoir, “Dear America: Notes of an Undocumented Citizen”.
Vargas\’ book follows his journey as a kid who was taken to the US as a 12 year old, his first experiences in America, and his coming out as gay to classmates and grandparents. Vargas often speaks about how as a Filipino, he did not fit in anywhere. When people referred to undocumented immigrants, they usually pointed towards the Latinex community. He noticed irregularities between how people treated illegal immigrants and more. In 2015, Vargas\’s documentary, Documented, 2015 NAACP Image Award nomination for Outstanding Documentary. MTV also aired his Emmy Nominated Special, White People, which detailed what it was like to be a young whie child in an America that was changning due to immigration and more. He received the Freedom to Write Award from PEN Center USA and degrees from Emerson College, Colby College, and the John Jay College of Criminal Justice. He, today, works on an adovisory board for TheDream.US, which provides scholarships to immigrant students who are undocumented.
https://www.theatlantic.com/entertainment/archive/2018/10/dear-america-jose-antonio-vargas-memoir-review/573013/ https://openborders.info/jose-antonio-vargas-life-story/ https://joseantoniovargas.com/about/
1. What happened to Vargas at a young age? He had a sister who was taken away because her papers were fake His parents died in a car crash He was smuggled into the United States His grandmother died of cancer
2. How did Vargas begin to learn about American culture after his grandfather admitted to him that his papers were purchased and fake and he felt he needed to fit in? Watch Hollywood movies Read all the American literature he could Thoroughly try to learn every aspect of the English language Spend time with gangs to learn American slang and culture
3. Which one of these is not a work that Vargas created to show the story of his life? The New York Times Magazine essay, “My Life as an Undocumented Immigrant” The essay, “Musings from an Angry Asian American Boy” A 2021 Time cover story, “Not Legal Not Leaving” A 2013 film, “Documented”
4. In Vargas/’s memoir, “Dear America: Notes of an Undocumented Citizen”, he talks about what? His journey of learning how to speak French and the challenges he faced due to his original language His journey of entering the US as a 12-year-old boy and his experiences of growing up as an undocumented immigrant His friend/’s journey of growing up as an undocumented citizen and how he helped his friend The story of his parents/’ journey into Spain as undocumented immigrants and how they overcame their challenges
5. MTV has aired Vargas/’s Emmy Nominated Special, “White People” which is about what? What it is like to be a young white child in an America that was changing due to immigration policies and other ones as well What it is like to be a young Latinx child in an America that was changing due to immigration policies and other ones as well The policies being passed in Congress that discriminated against Black people are their culture The fight Vargas faced against the government as he advocated for free health rights for all
//Jamey Jesperson Strings
Jamey Jesperson Pronouns: He/Him Gender: Male LGTBQ+ Rights Activist
Jamey Jesperson was born in California in 1994 to a family of Mormons. Jamey grew up with the idea that they could only be one of two genders, male or female. They were very feminine growing up, playing with toys that people believed only girls played with and hanging out with girls their age. Older men at their church were upset with Jesperson for doing so. Jesperson came out as gay in high school and came out as gender non-conforming at the age of 21. They received a lot of gossip as a result of coming out in a large Mormon community but fortunately, at the time, Jesperson was dating someone in a similar situation who helped them. Jesperson\’s parents were supportive of their identity and were always open. Jesperson however got a lot of disgust from the church, with people who started to ignore them and warning their children to stay away from Jesperson.
Jesperson started attending college at The New School in New York City. Jesperson was still following the Mormon faith because from young they had learned that prayer was the only way to deal with emotions such as anger, hate, and loneliness. One day, at church, Jesperson realized they did not want to associate with the church anymore. Many people in Jesperson\’s family were angered by their decision to leave and many of them distanced themself from Jesperson. Despite this, after Jesperson wrote an essay about the Mormon Church\’s anti- LGBTQ+ politics when the Mormon Church separated themselves from Boy Scouts after they started accepting girls, many of their family members supported them. Jesperson today is an LGBTQ+ activist who helps make sure that LGBTQ+ youth feel supported and comfortable. They are the Education Associate at GLSEN, which is an organization that works to bring LGBTQ+ students and children with resources they may need and teaches educators how to provide support. Jamey hopes to see youth comfortably identifying outside of the gender binary of male/female or boy/girl. They wish to spread awareness about how society and politics has pushed a rigid gender norm for youth and how it is influencing them.
https://www.gaystarnews.com/article/meet-jamey-jesperson-the-nonbinary-activist-who-left-the-mormon-church/ https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/boy-or-girl-parents-raising-theybies-let-kids-decide-n891836 https://freedomforallamericans.org/nonbinary-education-activist-we-have-to-embrace-everyones-authenticity/
//Laverne Cox Strings
Laverne Cox Pronouns: She/Her Gender: Female Trans Representation and Rights Activist
Laverne Cox was born on May 29, 1972 in Mobile, Alabama with a twin brother. She was bullied as a child, being called a sissy and the f-word. She did not act the way people assumed a person assigned male at gender would act and many disliked her for it. She was chased after school and beat up. Cox had a suicide attempt at age 11. One day, in third grade, Cox\’s teacher told her mother that her son was one day going to be wearing a dress in New Orleans. At the time, Cox did not know the difference between boys and girls, she just assumed she would turn into a girl after puberty. That was the moment she realized she was transgender.
Cox attended the Alabama School of Fine Arts in Birmingham and studied writing and dance there. She switched to Indiana University Bloomington and then Marymount Manhattan College in New York City when she began to study acting. She is known for her role as Sophia Burset, who is, according to Biography.com, “ an imprisoned trans woman who fights for appropriate hormone treatments and has a highly strained relationship with her son while also receiving love and acceptance from her wife”. In 2008, she was also featured in an episode of Law and Order: SVU and the TV show TRANSform Me (2010). Cox was the first trans person to be nominated an Emmy and appear on the cover of Times magazine. As a transgender activst, she has her own panel on the Hufington post and has written an essay on gender identidy and expression named, “Everybody\’s Trans: Gender Oppression Hurts All of Us”. In 2018, Cox became the first transgender woman to appear on the cover of Cosmopoliton, the South Africa edition. She is also the executive producer of Netflix documentary, “Disclosure” which reveals the challenges the trangender community faced over the years, the violence they faced, and movies and other productions that have allowed them to enter the industry.
https://www.nbcnews.com/feature/nbc-out/laverne-cox-details-transphobic-attack-it-s-not-safe-world-n1249334 https://www.biography.com/actor/laverne-cox https://ccrjustice.org/home/blog/2019/08/02/evening-activism-laverne-cox https://www.oprahmag.com/entertainment/tv-movies/a28987199/laverne-cox-facts/

//Resources Resources Suicide And Crisis LGBTQ+ Youth Alliances for Disorders Call: Next Back
Suicide Crisis The American Foundation for Suicide Prevention Provides referrals to support groups and mental health professionals, resources on loss, and suicide prevention information 888-333-2377 The National Domestic Violence Hotline Provides 24/7 crisis intervention, safety planning and information on domestic violence 800-799-7233 The Suicide Prevention Lifeline Connects callers to trained crisis counselors 800-273-8255
LGBTQ+ The Trevor Project The Trevor Project is the leading national organization providing crisis intervention and suicide prevention services to lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and questioning (LGBTQ) young people. 866-488-7386 SCO Family Therapy Intervention Program Provides free, short-term family counseling services to support parents and young people in working through challenges that might arise related to coming out. 516-671-1253 The Parents Project The Parents Project is a first-of-its-kind digital presence, inclusive of videos, advice, and resources, dedicated exclusively toward helping parents understand their LGBTQ kids. https://gaycenter.org/resources/#youth For more information, visit:
Alliances for Disorders Children and Adults with Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder(CHADD) Provides information and referrals on ADHD, including local support groups 800-233-4050 Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance (DBSA) Provides information on bipolar disorder and depression, offers in-person and online support groups and forums 800-826-3632 International OCD Foundation Provides information on OCD and treatment referrals 617-973-5801 National Center of Excellence for Eating Disorders (NCEED) Provides up-to-date, reliable and evidence-based information about eating disorders 800-931-2237 Schizophrenia and Related Disorders Alliance of America (SARDAA) Offers Schizophrenia Anonymous self-help groups and toll-free teleconferences 240-423-9432 Sidran Institute Helps people understand, manage and treat trauma and dissociation; maintains a helpline for information and referrals 410-825-8888 Treatment and Research Advancements for Borderline Personality Disorder Offers a referral center for information, support, education and treatment options for BPD 888-482-7227
